sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Addressing hazardous drinking during medical-surgical care improves patients’ health. This formative evaluation examined patients’ consideration of options to change drinking and engage in treatment. It explored whether interventions such as “DO-MoST” overcome treatment barriers. We interviewed 20 medical-surgical patients with hazardous drinking in a trial of DO-MoST, and 16 providers. Analyses used a directed content approach. Patients were receptive to and comfortable discussing drinking during medical-surgical care. Interventions like DO-MoST (patient-centered, motivational approach to shared decision making) addressed some treatment barriers. Patients and providers viewed such interventions as helpful by building a relationship with a psychologist who facilitated self-awareness of drinking behaviors, and discussing connections between alcohol- and physical health-related problems and potential strategies to address drinking. However, both groups expressed concerns about individual and system-level barriers to long-term change. Interventions like DO-MoST bridge the gap between the patient’s medical treatment episode and transition to other health care settings.

sec.title: Trial Registration
sec.p: The study is registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (ID: NCT03258632).

body.p: Hazardous drinking refers to drinking more than recommended limits, including meeting diagnostic criteria for an alcohol use disorder (AUD). Hazardous drinking is common among patients receiving inpatient or outpatient specialty medical-surgical care. About 25% of adults admitted to general hospitals in the US have AUDs or are being treated for drinking consequences (Brgdar et al., 2022); (Shah et al., 2022); (Wei et al., 2015). This likely underrepresents the prevalence of hazardous drinking among medical-surgical patients because alcohol-related problems often go undiagnosed during hospital stays and clinic visits (Danovitch et al., 2021). For example, a study at one hospital found that 29% of patients screened as having high-risk alcohol use had no alcohol-related codes associated with hospital admission (Wakeman et al., 2020).

Hazardous drinking and medical-surgical conditions are interrelated via three primary pathways (Timko et al., 2016a); (Timko et al., 2016b). Hazardous drinking may be a causal factor in developing a medical condition (e.g. liver disease, traumatic injury), may exacerbate health conditions that developed apart from drinking (e.g. diabetes), and may complicate effective management of existing medical conditions through poor adherence to medications and to diet, no-smoking, and physical activity recommendations. Alcohol use prior to surgery is associated with during- and post-surgery complications, and patients with AUD have poorer post-surgery outcomes (Bernstein et al., 2022). In addition, hazardous drinking co-occurring with medical-surgical conditions increases costly health services use. Medical inpatients with AUD were 1.6 times more likely to be readmitted within 30 days of discharge than those without AUD (Wei et al., 2015). Indeed, alcohol-related disorders are among the diagnostic categories with the highest rates of rapid hospital readmission (Gryczynski et al., 2021). In a study of inpatients and outpatients from 44 centers in the National COVID Cohort Collaborative, adults with COVID-19 and AUD (n = 25,583) had higher odds of hospitalization and mortality compared to adults with COVID-19 but without AUD (n = 1,309,445), even when analyses adjusted for patients’ demographic and clinical characteristics (Bailey et al., 2022).

These findings on the co-occurrence and consequences of hazardous drinking and medical conditions underscore the importance of identifying and addressing hazardous drinking to improve medical-surgical patients’ health. Medical care in the hospital or specialty outpatient clinic is an opportunity for psychologists to address hazardous drinking. It represents a teachable moment to conduct a behavioral intervention to initiate alcohol treatment (Bradley & Kivlahan, 2014). An alcohol-related intervention during a medical care episode has the potential to facilitate treatment for alcohol use by increasing recognition of the need to reduce drinking, intent to do so, and awareness that engagement in alcohol treatment could be useful to reduce drinking.

In light of the importance of better understanding how to encourage behavior change among medical-surgical patients with hazardous drinking, we developed a patient-centered intervention to improve alcohol treatment and/or mutual-help utilization (initiation and engagement) and outcomes (less or no drinking and better health). This approach is “Drinking Options—Motivate, Shared Decisions, Telemonitor” (DO-MoST) (Fig. 1). DO-MoST, begun during the medical care episode, is intended to facilitate transitioning to help that is evidence based (i.e., behavioral and/or pharmacological treatment, mutual-help groups) and to improve outcomes (Bradley & Kivlahan, 2014; Elwyn et al., 2014). Its development was informed by our previous implementation of treatment facilitation interventions with other patient populations (Ilgen et al., 2022; Timko et al., 2018, 2019). Delivered by a Decision Coach (master’s or doctorate level trained clinical provider), DO-MoST has three components: motivational interviewing approach to motivate patients to change drinking and initiate help seeking; use of a decision aid for patients to choose the type of evidence-based help they prefer and need; and telemonitoring to support and monitor patients’ initiation of and engagement in their preferred modality of help (or, for patients not motivated to change, telemonitoring to continue motivational interviewing). Motivational interviewing respects and works with patients’ ambivalence about changing drinking; the decision aid informs patients about the evidence behind different help sources so they can choose their preferred help source based on their needs; and telemonitoring continues to work with ambivalence as needed and provide support for patients’ choices (DiClemente et al., 2017; Donovan et al., 2015). DO-MoST is designed to be intensive enough to produce change yet feasible to use in busy clinical settings with too much demand on too few staff with psychology training. It draws on approaches that are evidence based but have not been used together in an integrated way.Fig. 1
Drinking Options—Motivate, Shared Decisions, Telemonitor (DO-MoST) by clinical psychologist providers

We are currently conducting a randomized trial of usual care plus DO-MoST compared to usual care alone. Patients in DO-MoST attend one 50-min individual session (in-person or by telephone) and six biweekly 15-min telephone sessions with the Decision Coach. At the initial session, the Decision Coach and patient engage in motivational interviewing to discuss the patient’s medical condition and need to make decisions about drinking goals (abstinence, moderation, or no change), and the goals’ benefits and adverse effects. If the patient prefers to reduce or abstain from drinking and will consider obtaining help, the decision aid is employed to present evidence-based help options (medications, behavioral therapies, mutual help) and their benefits, adverse effects, and settings (e.g. primary care, specialty care). At the session’s end, patients complete a brief measure of their drinking and help preferences. If the patient is ready, a list with the location and contact number for each potential selected source of help is used to make the next step in obtaining help concrete.

During each telephone session, patients complete the same progress assessment worksheet which includes drinking and help preferences, and answer questions about recent substance use, treatment, and mutual-help attendance. Patients indicating during the initial session that they do not want to change receive motivational interviewing during the telephone sessions. For patients indicating during the initial session willingness to initiate help, phone calls are used to make sure patients understand the help options available, the benefits and risks of each, and the specific next step needed to pursue the selected help option. Telemonitoring provides support when help is obtained, and problem solving on barriers to help initiation, and/or discussions of ways to improve patients’ experience in accessing help. For example, coaches help patients work through the potential situation that a treatment provider suggests a different help option than the one the patient has selected. Telephone monitoring supports patients in moving from help initiation to help engagement.

The present study was a formative evaluation to document critical factors at the patient, provider, and system levels that affect the likelihood that patients with hazardous drinking seen in medical-surgical settings will consider options to change their drinking and engage in treatment. In addition, the study explored whether a patient-centered intervention such as DO-MoST may overcome barriers to initiation of alcohol-related services and/or mutual help. The study draws from a conceptual model that describes patient characteristics and resources, provider experience within and across care sites, and system-level collaboration and feedback as facilitators and barriers to health care transitions (Cucciare et al., 2014, 2015; Timko et al., 2016a, 2016b). We conducted qualitative interviews to examine patients’ perspectives on alcohol use being brought up during treatment for a medical-surgical condition. Interviews were also intended to identify providers’ views of barriers to patients receiving alcohol treatment in the context of current medical care, and patients’ views of if and how interventions such as DO-MoST benefit patients, including which barriers they address. This study expands previous literature on intervening with patients having co-occurring alcohol and medical-surgical problems to engage in alcohol treatment by systematically and qualitatively examining factors that promote and hinder treatment initiation, from a provider perspective. It also examines patients’ views of addressing alcohol use generally in the context of medical treatment, and of a specific intervention delivered by master’s or doctorate level clinical psychologists, DO-MoST, which has not been evaluated before.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Eligibility criteria for patients’ participation in the trial are (1) in a current episode of inpatient or specialty outpatient medical-surgical care, (2) score of ≥ 4 (men) or ≥ 3 (women) on the AUDIT-C (i.e., positive screen for hazardous drinking), (3) no specialty addiction treatment or weekly mutual-help group attendance within 60 days prior to the care episode, (4) no significant cognitive impairment (indicated with the Montreal Cognitive Assessment section on orientation; (Nasreddine et al., 2005), (5) ongoing access to a cellular or landline telephone, and (6) at least one contact who knows the patient’s contact information. Patients were located at two facilities (Midwestern and Western US) in the same health care system. All patients enrolled in the trial were alerted during the initial consent process that they may be contacted for participation in the formative evaluation (the qualitative) component of the study.

We attempted to telephone 27 trial participants to ask them to participate in a qualitative interview. These 27 patients were selected consecutively based on their randomized condition assignment to DO-MoST during the second half of the recruitment period and their completion of the 12-month follow-up assessment. Of the 27 patients we attempted to call, 7 (26%) did not answer the phone and 20 (74%) agreed to participate, provided informed consent, and completed the interview. sec.title: Providers
sec.p: To recruit providers, senior study staff identified clinical providers of care to medical-surgical patients with hazardous drinking (i.e., psychologists, social workers, unit or clinic physician-directors, nurses) and emailed them. The email briefly explained the purpose of the overall project and interview, and invited the individual to participate. We followed the email with a phone call to answer any questions the provider may have had about the project and to schedule the interview. Of 31 providers emailed, 15 (48%) did not respond to the email and 16 (52%) agreed to participate and were interviewed. Providers gave informed consent prior to the interview, and were prohibited by the health care system from receiving remuneration. Providers interviewed (6 nurses, with the other groups equally represented) were given a standardized summary of DO-MoST’s components and procedures before the interview began. Providers’ characteristics are in Table 1. Interviews with providers lasted from 30 to 45 min.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Draft interview guides were prepared by senior study staff and finalized with feedback from the full study team and pre-testing with two providers. Interviews were conducted by senior study staff (Drs. Timko, Blonigen, and Ilgen, experts in the content and methods of this study) and research assistants (Ms. Lewis, Ms. Lor, and Ms. Aldaco-Revilla) who were trained in carrying out such interviews. We used semi-structured interviews with specified prompts to understand how patients with hazardous drinking may be approached about their alcohol use, the process of changing alcohol use, and care utilization, and their experiences with the DO-MoST intervention. Researchers and participants did not have relationships prior to interacting for the study.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: In the semi-structured interviews, patients were asked what they thought about being approached to discuss their alcohol use while in treatment for a medical-surgical condition. These questions provided data about their impressions of the broader components of alcohol interventions. Specifically, they were asked about “providing patients with alcohol treatment resources available to them that they might not have known about, and seeing if patients might make changes to their drinking habits.” A prompt related to this topic was how well interviewees thought these discussions would meet the needs of patients in medical or surgical treatment who may need help in reducing their drinking.

Patients were also asked specific questions to examine their perspectives on DO-MoST’s effectiveness. Effectiveness is a dimension contained in the RE-AIM framework, which was developed to translate scientific advances into practice (Glasgow et al., 2019). Patients were asked: “Tell me about your overall experience with DO-MoST. What did you like and dislike about DO-MoST? What did you find most and least helpful about DO-MoST?” Related prompts were “Did DO-MoST meet your expectations—why or why not? To what extent has DO-MoST impacted, positively or negatively, your health care, if at all? Your quality of life?”

sec.title: Providers
sec.p: The interviews examined providers’ perspectives on barriers at the patient, program, and system levels that affect medical-surgical patients’ initiation and engagement in alcohol treatment. The interview guide adapted the conceptual model developed by (Cucciare et al., 2014) on care transitions. Specific to identifying barriers, providers were asked: “What do you think the barriers are for your patients about discussing their alcohol use,” and, “What are some of the barriers you face with providing alcohol treatment options to patients during appointments or hospital stays?” Prompts related to these questions were “How comfortable are you when recommending alcohol treatment to patients, and what kind of help or support would you need to be more comfortable?” Additional prompts were, “What are common questions or concerns you hear about alcohol treatment from your patients,” and, “What are some of the benefits you could see from discussing alcohol treatment options with patients during appointments or inpatient stays?”

sec.title: Analysis Plan
sec.p: Interviews were audio recorded (with permission). The study’s data analysis approach consisted of directed content analysis using interview notes and verification with audio recordings (Nevedal et al., 2021). The interviewer took notes and captured quotations for each question during interviews. Immediately after the interviews, the interviewer coded the notes into an MS Excel file that contained the question matrix and noted when additional detail or a timestamp was needed. The primary analyst then reviewed the matrix, listened to the audio recordings when indicated, and edited and built upon the interviewer’s notes. The secondary analyst also reviewed the matrix, listened to the audio recordings when indicated, and edited and built upon the primary analyst’s notes. Analysts coded based on a codebook with deductive general alcohol discussion and effectiveness constructs (patient data), and patient, provider, and system-level constructs (provider data) as well as inductive codes that were relevant to the evaluation. Analysts used comments and highlighting in the matrix to flag sections of text for discussion and met to adjudicate differences and refine the codebook.

sec.title: Patient Reports of Discussing Alcohol use During Medical-Surgical Care
sec.p:
Patients’ general reactions to their alcohol use being discussed in the course of medical-surgical treatment contained three themes (Table 2). First, these discussions helped patients’ think about their drinking in general; that is, they helped patients see the consequences of their alcohol use, and find out how to get help for drinking and change their use of alcohol (reduce or abstain from alcohol use). The second theme was that discussions about alcohol use helped patients improve their medical-surgical or mental health conditions, specifically. The third theme was that bringing up alcohol use during medical-surgical treatment would not help patients who do not see themselves as having problems regarding their drinking.Table 2

[Other health care system’s] clinics do the same procedures to get veterans connected to services…. You just have to let them know that it [drinking] is very important and so they can be treated. Although not specifically asked in the interview questions, 7 patients advised on how to bring up alcohol use with patients during medical-surgical treatment (not tabled). The advice was to lead gradually to the topic of alcohol use, and to take a caring, non-confrontational, and non-judgmental approach, emphasizing confidentiality; for example: “With the conversation in the beginning, it is universal or global that helps people to get hooked on it and slowly go to the drinking problem” (study ID: PAHE1). One patient advised, “It is really good to feel that someone out there is interested in the care of the person in need. And to look into the situation—whether or not the person can be taken away from the alcohol or drug use in a manner that is not subjected to harm or demeaning or any of that” (PAME3).

sec.p:

Low motivation and denial included patients’ lack of readiness to change or discuss drinking due to their beliefs that harms of drinking were irreversible. Providers stated that patients feared experiencing withdrawal symptoms, and had low self-efficacy to change drinking due to previous “failed” treatments. Providers also noted the barrier of low availability of treatments that patients want. For example, some patients want residential treatment when only outpatient treatment is available, and when patients see outpatient treatment as acceptable, they would prefer individual treatment but are referred to group treatment. Providers saw another barrier to alcohol care as the stigmatization of addiction and patients’ shame of drinking too heavily, and another as patients’ life context; that is, patients’ problems of living related to their finances, housing insecurity, and lack of transportation and social support take precedence to or interfere with treatment initiation. Similarly, patients’ co-occurring health problems, such as poor mental health, chronic pain, insomnia, and cognitive impairment, make initiating alcohol care beyond the patient’s capability. This is likely exacerbated when patients lack the means (e.g. a phone) to make an appointment. Another patient-level barrier to alcohol care reported by providers is the home environment supporting substance use rather than abstinence.

Provider reports of treatment and setting barriers to medical-surgical patients receiving alcohol care were fewer in number compared to patient-level barriers. The three themes represented were lack of an ongoing provider–patient relationship, such as one that allows trust to develop over time (especially in inpatient settings); lack of providers’ confidence in alcohol care patients may receive, and lack of providers’ comfort with discussing and treating substance use. Only one theme representing a system barrier was reported by providers. This was lack of inpatient or outpatient clinic access to treatment resources for immediate handoff, including detoxification services and outpatient and residential alcohol care.

sec.title: Patient-Reported Effectiveness of DO-MoST
sec.p:
The effectiveness of DO-MoST, reported by patients, was represented in seven themes (Table 4). The first was the patient’s relationship with the Decision Coach. Patients described the relationship as providing support, accountability, and information, and helping to fill the treatment gap. That the Decision Coach offered help on the phone over time was seen as a benefit of DO-MoST; calls were conveniently timed and completed from home over a sustained period. Patients’ themes related to DO-MoST’s effectiveness were also represented by perceptions that DO-MoST helped with their self-evaluation and self-awareness, as well as creation of a change plan. DO-MoST was seen as facilitating reduced drinking, a better life due to positive consequences of less drinking (e.g. more involvement in activities, more responsible, better relationships), and better physical and mental health.Table 4

When coding patients’ responses regarding the effectiveness of DO-MoST, we also documented patients’ suggestions on how DO-MoST should be changed to provide more benefit (not tabled). The most common themes were to replace a small number of DO-MoST’s phone calls with in-person or video meetings (n = 8) and to offer more flexibility in terms of scheduling the phone calls (n = 3).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study, using qualitative data from medical-surgical patients with untreated hazardous alcohol use and from health care providers, supports three broad conclusions. First, patients with untreated hazardous alcohol use are receptive to discussing their drinking during a medical-surgical care episode. Second, interventions delivered by clinical psychologists such as DO-MoST, that take a motivational approach to shared decision making over time using telephone sessions, address some but not all of the barriers providers identified to patients’ obtaining help for hazardous drinking. Finally, patients viewed interventions such as DO-MoST as potentially helpful for reducing drinking by means of building a relationship with a coach who facilitated self-awareness of drinking behaviors and how to change drinking.

Patients had positive views of being approached about their use of alcohol during a medical-surgical care episode. They thought that such discussions could help patients see that their drinking was problematic, learn about options for treatment, reduce or quit drinking, and have a better quality of life, although they cautioned that patients have to “be ready” to be helped. Patients also thought that such discussions could help improve both medical and mental health conditions. These views held by patients were consistent with provider-identified barriers to medical-surgical patients obtaining alcohol-related care, which included patients’ denial of having drinking problems and lack of motivation to change drinking. Patients’ views are also consistent with their evaluations of DO-MoST specifically, which was seen as overcoming these provider-identified barriers by facilitating patients’ awareness of problematic drinking, creation of a change plan, drinking less, and having better health. Motivation to change drinking has been shown to be an important predictor of better alcohol use outcomes (Collins et al., 2012) and to be high among patients hospitalized for medical problems such as cardiovascular conditions (Siewert-Markus et al., 2022), and, thus, is a potentially important target for alcohol interventions in medical care settings. Motivation is seen as a dynamic and fluctuating state that can be modified by approaches to arouse and enhance it (CSAT, 2013; (Vederhus et al., 2014). Motivational approaches may have the additional advantage of helping patients with other patient-level barriers that providers identified in the present study, such as inflexibility regarding the desired type of treatment sought, the stigma of addiction and its treatment, and having other life context needs that supersede changing drinking.

Interventions such as DO-MoST address an important provider-identified barrier to patients’ obtaining alcohol care: the absence of a provider-patient relationship (Gressler et al., 2019). This barrier was explained as due to providers’ lack of time to spend with patients to develop trust and a safe space in which patients could open up about their needs regarding alcohol use. Consistently, patients saw their relationship with a decision coach as a benefit of DO-MoST. A coach provided a caring and concerned listener who was non-judgmental but also offered accountability. In addition, a coach filled the gap between discharge from the medical-surgical care episode and initiation of available alcohol treatment. Patient–provider trust is also modifiable, in that specialized provider training that includes work on trust building for individuals with substance use disorders (SUDs) is feasible and potentially improves the quality of care and health outcomes for patients with these disorders (Bohnert et al., 2011). The present study’s patient interviews suggest that trust building and its positive consequences can be achieved with the use of interventions such as DO-MoST that are offered by telephone. Well known is that the COVID-19 pandemic led to an increase in the use of telehealth technologies (Deng et al., 2022); (Torous et al., 2021) and evidence suggests a positive association of patients’ trust in the provider and their satisfaction with telehealth visits (Orrange et al., 2021). The benefits of telehealth may be particularly notable when the patient has had the ability to establish an initial connection with the provider (in this case, the Decision Coach) and the telephone contacts are used to build on this initial interaction and help enact and refine the plans that were developed during this initial session.

While efforts such as DO-MoST address important provider-identified barriers to patients’ alcohol care, they do not address the barrier of the systemic lack of treatment resources. Indeed, despite the high prevalence, mortality, and economic costs of hazardous drinking, only 8.3% of 15.8 million US adults who reported needing treatment for an alcohol problem received specialty alcohol treatment (Kranzler & Soyka, 2018). More specifically, national US data indicate that persons with AUDs commonly utilize health care and are often screened about alcohol use, but few receive treatment, supporting the view that health care settings represent a prime opportunity to implement behavioral interventions to facilitate alcohol treatment to improve patient outcomes (Mintz et al., 2021). Consistent with our results for patients, another study using national US data from 2004 to 2017 found that a growing proportion of older adults sought first-time SUD treatment in residential facilities (Huhn et al., 2019). For patients who receive alcohol care in residential facilities, continuing care by telehealth technologies has been shown to be effective in that it reduced the number risky drinking days compared to a control condition (Gustafson et al., 2014).

It is important to discuss approaches such as DO-MoST in the context of other efforts to increase access to and use of alcohol care in medical-surgical settings, such as inpatient consultation services. For example, (Englander et al., 2019) noted that while hospitalizations due to medical-surgical complications of SUDs are rising, most hospitals lack systems to treat SUD, and most people with SUDs do not engage in post-discharge treatment. They conducted a cohort study comparing Improving Addiction Care Team (IMPACT) patients with propensity-matched controls. IMPACT was more intensive and extensive than DO-MoST in that it included hospital-based consultation care from an interdisciplinary team of addiction medicine physicians, social workers, and peers with lived experience in recovery. It met with patients during hospitalization to offer pharmacotherapy, behavioral treatments, and harm reduction services, and supported linkages to SUD treatment after discharge. The main finding was that IMPACT patients engaged in post-discharge SUD treatment more often than controls did (39% vs 23%). A qualitative study of IMPACT found that peers in particular were able to help build trust with patients and also facilitated patient care by contextualizing patient experiences to providers (Collins et al., 2019). However, the study also noted that integrating peer mentors into hospital care presents substantial challenges (Collins et al., 2019).

Wakeman et al. (2017) similarly conducted a prospective quasi-experimental evaluation comparing 30-day post-discharge outcomes between hospitalized patients (screened as having, or at high risk for, SUD) who did or did not receive addiction consultation. Addiction consultation consisted of a multidisciplinary specialty team offering pharmacotherapy, motivational counseling, treatment planning, and direct linkage to ongoing addiction treatment. Results were that the intervention group decreased more than the control group on alcohol and drug use severity, and increased more on number of abstinent days. Subsequently, (Wakeman et al.’s 2021) randomized controlled trial tested the incremental benefit of telephone linkage to a post-discharge navigator among patients who had received addiction consultation during hospitalization. The intervention attempted four post-discharge phone calls from a navigator to review the recommended treatment plan and address barriers to engagement. At 1-month follow-up, both groups reduced alcohol and drug use compared to baseline, but there was no difference between groups at the 1- or 2-month follow-up. Follow-up rates were low at both 1 month (46%) and 2 months (41%).

In related work, Gryczynski et al., (2021) conducted a randomized controlled trial comparing Navigation Services to Avoid Rehospitalization (NavSTAR) to treatment as usual with hospitalized adults having co-occurring SUDs and medical conditions. NavSTAR used case management, advocacy, service linkage, and motivational support to resolve barriers to care and address SUD, medical, and basic needs for 3 months post-discharge. Patients in NavSTAR compared to patients in treatment as usual were less likely to have an inpatient readmission within 30 days of discharge (16% vs. 30%) and were more likely to enter community SUD care within 3 months of discharge (50% vs. 35%).

The intervention services offered in the studies led by Englander, Wakeman, and Gryczynski were more extensive and likely more costly than services offered by interventions such as DO-MoST. Although addiction consultation and navigation services were more successful than usual care at linking patients to substance use treatment, one-half or more of patients receiving these services did not initiate treatment (Englander et al., 2019; Gryczynski et al., 2021). Additional work is needed to both complete the current trial of DO-MoST and to determine in randomized trials the success of less intensive and costly approaches such as DO-MoST versus more extensive consultation and navigation services in connecting patients to care and improving their substance use outcomes.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Although this study had strengths (e.g. use of a care transition conceptual model to guide interviews), it also had limitations. Specifically, the sample consisted of patients and providers only in one health care system (US Veterans Health Administration [VHA] medical facilities), which may limit the generalizability of findings. However, VHA is the largest health care system in the US, and performance data show that health care provided in VHA is similar to or better than that in non-VHA health care systems (Anhang Price et al., 2018). In addition, findings may not generalize to patients who refused participation in the randomized trial of DO-MoST, to patients currently engaged in alcohol treatment, or to patients who are more diverse in terms of gender, race, and ethnicity. Further, we did not examine whether provider views differed across discipline, and this is an important direction for future research.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Although hazardous alcohol use is common in medical-surgical patients, few evidence-based resources exist to leverage medical visits as a time for clinical psychologists to address hazardous alcohol use. Qualitative data from patients who participated in the DO-MoST intervention indicated that medical-surgical patients with hazardous alcohol use are comfortable discussing their drinking and derive benefit from discussing the relationship between their alcohol- and physical health-related problems, as well as potential strategies to address their alcohol use. Providers also see the potential benefits of such an approach, but both groups express concerns about potential individual and system-level barriers to long-term change. An intervention that utilizes a motivational approach to shared decisions – DO-MoST – was generally well-received and the combination of an initial session with multiple follow-up calls allowed the intervention to bridge the time period from the index medical treatment episode and when the patient transitioned to other settings. Once available, the randomized trial outcome data will indicate whether the relatively positive response to this intervention translates into sustained changes in alcohol use over time.
